title: Fourier Series
explanation:
Introduction to Fourier Series

Fourier series represents periodic signals as a sum of sinusoids. Any periodic signal can be decomposed into a DC component plus harmonically related sine and cosine waves.

Trigonometric Fourier Series

For a periodic signal $x(t)$ with period $T_0$ and fundamental frequency $\omega_0 = \frac{2\pi}{T_0}$:

$x(t) = a_0 + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}[a_n\cos(n\omega_0 t) + b_n\sin(n\omega_0 t)]$

Coefficients:

  • DC component: $a_0 = \frac{1}{T_0}\int_{T_0} x(t)dt$ (average value)
  • Cosine coefficients: $a_n = \frac{2}{T_0}\int_{T_0} x(t)\cos(n\omega_0 t)dt$
  • Sine coefficients: $b_n = \frac{2}{T_0}\int_{T_0} x(t)\sin(n\omega_0 t)dt$

üí° The nth harmonic has frequency $n\omega_0 = n \cdot \frac{2\pi}{T_0}$

Exponential Fourier Series

Using Euler's formula: $e^{j\theta} = \cos\theta + j\sin\theta$

$x(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} c_n e^{jn\omega_0 t}$

where: $c_n = \frac{1}{T_0}\int_{T_0} x(t)e^{-jn\omega_0 t}dt$

Relationship with trigonometric form:

  • $c_0 = a_0$ (DC component)
  • $c_n = \frac{a_n - jb_n}{2}$ for $n > 0$
  • $c_{-n} = c_n^*$ (complex conjugate for real signals)
  • $|c_n| = \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{a_n^2 + b_n^2}$ (magnitude spectrum)

Symmetry Properties

Signal Symmetry Condition Fourier Coefficients
Even Function $x(t) = x(-t)$ $b_n = 0$ (only cosines, $c_n$ real)
Odd Function $x(t) = -x(-t)$ $a_n = 0$ (only sines, $c_n$ imaginary)
Half-Wave Symmetry $x(t) = -x(t \pm T_0/2)$ Only odd harmonics ($n$ odd)

‚ö†Ô∏è Symmetry properties can significantly reduce computation!

Dirichlet Conditions

A periodic signal has a Fourier series if it satisfies:

  • 1. Absolutely integrable: $\int_{T_0}|x(t)|dt < \infty$
  • 2. Finite number of maxima and minima in one period
  • 3. Finite number of discontinuities in one period

üí° At discontinuities, series converges to the average of left and right limits

Parseval's Theorem

Relates time-domain energy to frequency-domain energy:

$\frac{1}{T_0}\int_{T_0}|x(t)|^2 dt = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}|c_n|^2 = a_0^2 + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(a_n^2 + b_n^2)$

üéØ Total average power equals sum of powers in all harmonics

Gibbs Phenomenon

When representing discontinuous signals:

  • Overshoot of ~9% persists near discontinuities
  • Occurs no matter how many terms are used
  • Oscillations concentrate at discontinuity as N ‚Üí ‚àû

Common Waveforms

1. Square Wave (period T‚ÇÄ, amplitude A):

$x(t) = \frac{4A}{\pi}\sum_{n=1,3,5...}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sin(n\omega_0 t)$

2. Sawtooth Wave:

$x(t) = \frac{2A}{\pi}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n}\sin(n\omega_0 t)$

3. Triangle Wave:

$x(t) = \frac{8A}{\pi^2}\sum_{n=1,3,5...}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{(n-1)/2}}{n^2}\cos(n\omega_0 t)$

Applications

  • Audio Processing: Harmonic analysis, synthesis
  • Communications: Bandwidth requirements, spectral analysis
  • Power Systems: Harmonic distortion analysis
  • Signal Compression: JPEG, MP3 (DCT/MDCT based on Fourier)
  • Vibration Analysis: Mechanical systems, structural health monitoring

quiz.question: What is the fundamental frequency œâ‚ÇÄ of a periodic signal with period T‚ÇÄ = 0.1 seconds?
quiz.explanation: The fundamental frequency is $\omega_0 = \frac{2\pi}{T_0} = \frac{2\pi}{0.1} = 20\pi$ rad/s ‚âà 62.83 rad/s. This is the angular frequency of the first harmonic, and all other harmonics are integer multiples of this frequency.

quiz.question: If a signal x(t) is an even function (symmetric about t=0), which Fourier coefficients are zero?
quiz.explanation: For even functions where $x(t) = x(-t)$, all sine coefficients are zero ($b_n = 0$) because the product of an even function and an odd function (sine) integrates to zero over a symmetric interval. The Fourier series contains only cosine terms plus a DC component.

quiz.question: What does Parseval's theorem state for Fourier series?
options: Time and frequency representations are equivalent
Average power in time domain equals sum of powers in frequency domain
quiz.explanation: Parseval's theorem states that $\frac{1}{T_0}\int_{T_0}|x(t)|^2 dt = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}|c_n|^2$. This means the average power computed in the time domain equals the sum of powers of all frequency components. It's a fundamental energy conservation principle.

exercises.problem: Find the trigonometric Fourier series for a square wave with period T‚ÇÄ = 2œÄ, amplitude A = 1, that is +1 for 0 < t < œÄ and -1 for œÄ < t < 2œÄ.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • Period: $T_0 = 2\pi$, so $\omega_0 = 1$ rad/s
  • $x(t) = \begin{cases} 1, & 0 < t < \pi \\ -1, & \pi < t < 2\pi \end{cases}$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Calculate DC component

$a_0 = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}x(t)dt = \frac{1}{2\pi}[\int_0^{\pi}1\,dt + \int_{\pi}^{2\pi}(-1)dt] = \frac{1}{2\pi}[\pi - \pi] = 0$

Step 2: Check for symmetry

Signal is odd: $x(t) = -x(-t)$, therefore $a_n = 0$ for all n

Step 3: Calculate sine coefficients

$b_n = \frac{2}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}x(t)\sin(nt)dt = \frac{1}{\pi}[\int_0^{\pi}\sin(nt)dt - \int_{\pi}^{2\pi}\sin(nt)dt]$

$= \frac{1}{\pi}\left[\frac{-\cos(nt)}{n}\Big|_0^{\pi} + \frac{\cos(nt)}{n}\Big|_{\pi}^{2\pi}\right]$

$= \frac{1}{n\pi}[-\cos(n\pi) + 1 + \cos(2n\pi) - \cos(n\pi)]$

$= \frac{2}{n\pi}[1 - \cos(n\pi)] = \begin{cases} \frac{4}{n\pi}, & n \text{ odd} \\ 0, & n \text{ even} \end{cases}$

Step 4: Final answer

$x(t) = \frac{4}{\pi}\sum_{n=1,3,5,...}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sin(nt) = \frac{4}{\pi}\left[\sin(t) + \frac{1}{3}\sin(3t) + \frac{1}{5}\sin(5t) + ...\right]$

exercises.problem: A periodic signal has exponential Fourier series coefficients: c‚ÇÄ = 2, c‚ÇÅ = 1+j, c‚Çã‚ÇÅ = 1-j, c‚ÇÇ = 0.5, c‚Çã‚ÇÇ = 0.5. Calculate the average power of the signal.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • $c_0 = 2$, $c_1 = 1+j$, $c_{-1} = 1-j$
  • $c_2 = 0.5$, $c_{-2} = 0.5$

Formula: Parseval's Theorem

$P_{avg} = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}|c_n|^2$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Calculate $|c_0|^2$

$|c_0|^2 = |2|^2 = 4$

Step 2: Calculate $|c_1|^2$

$|c_1|^2 = |1+j|^2 = 1^2 + 1^2 = 2$

Step 3: Calculate $|c_{-1}|^2$

$|c_{-1}|^2 = |1-j|^2 = 1^2 + (-1)^2 = 2$

Step 4: Calculate $|c_2|^2$ and $|c_{-2}|^2$

$|c_2|^2 = |0.5|^2 = 0.25$

$|c_{-2}|^2 = |0.5|^2 = 0.25$

Step 5: Sum all powers

$P_{avg} = 4 + 2 + 2 + 0.25 + 0.25 = 8.5$ W

Step 6: Final answer

Average power = 8.5 W

Note: Power is distributed across DC (4 W), 1st harmonic (4 W total), and 2nd harmonic (0.5 W total)

exercises.problem: Convert the trigonometric Fourier series $x(t) = 3 + 4\cos(\omega_0 t) + 2\sin(\omega_0 t)$ to exponential form.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • $x(t) = 3 + 4\cos(\omega_0 t) + 2\sin(\omega_0 t)$
  • $a_0 = 3$, $a_1 = 4$, $b_1 = 2$

Formulas:

$c_0 = a_0$

$c_n = \frac{a_n - jb_n}{2}$ for $n > 0$

$c_{-n} = c_n^*$ (complex conjugate)

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Find $c_0$

$c_0 = a_0 = 3$

Step 2: Find $c_1$

$c_1 = \frac{a_1 - jb_1}{2} = \frac{4 - j2}{2} = 2 - j$

Step 3: Find $c_{-1}$ (complex conjugate)

$c_{-1} = c_1^* = 2 + j$

Step 4: Verify using Euler's formula

$2e^{j\omega_0 t} - je^{j\omega_0 t} = 2(\cos\omega_0 t + j\sin\omega_0 t) - j(\cos\omega_0 t + j\sin\omega_0 t)$

$= 2\cos\omega_0 t + \sin\omega_0 t + j(2\sin\omega_0 t - \cos\omega_0 t)$

When combined with $c_{-1}$, imaginary parts cancel ‚úì

Step 5: Final answer

$x(t) = 3e^{j0} + (2-j)e^{j\omega_0 t} + (2+j)e^{-j\omega_0 t}$

Or: $x(t) = \sum_{n=-1}^{1}c_n e^{jn\omega_0 t}$ where $c_{-1}=2+j, c_0=3, c_1=2-j$
